poem:
Van Gogh in the Living Room  

In the frame's embrace,  
a rush of lavender  
touches the eye's  
quiet plea—paint  
blends the song of  
stars and sunflowers,  
stretching beyond  
museum walls—  
in flickers of film,  
art's tender reach  
unfurls, finds the pulse  
of distant hearts,  
offering dreams  
to those who've  
never walked the halls.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Van Gogh: Poets & Lovers review – blockbuster portrait of a thoughtful master There’s a steepled-fingers argument to be had about whether live-event or gallery movies can ever compare to the thrill of seeing things for real and, furthermore, whether they undermine the in-person culture economy. The counter-argument, of course, is that these event films extend an opera/play/show’s reach and give access to an audience who would otherwise never get to experience it, even at". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
